awd_titl_txt: CIF: Large: Collaborative Research:  Cooperation and Learning over Cognitive Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Cooperation and Learning over Cognitive Networks
Studies on herding and self-organization in economics and the social and biological sciences have observed that coordination among multiple agents leads to regular patterns of behavior and swarm intelligence, even when each group member shows limited behavioral complexity. In ant colonies, for example, individual ants cannot capture rich spatial information from their environment because of their limited sensing ability. Nevertheless, when the ants coordinate their activities within a colony, the group ends up exhibiting better sensing abilities. Using signal processing and communications techniques, the research studies how and why such manifestations of rational and organized behavior arise at the group level from local interactions among agents with limited abilities, what communication topologies enable such behavior, and what type of signal processing enables such formations.  

This research seeks to understand and reverse-engineer the distributed intelligence encountered in socio-economic-biological networks, by investigating relations with learning and rationality over cognitive networks. The latter are adaptive networks that avoid centralized information processing and perform in-network inference and control decisions. Cognitive networks contrast with networks that rely on centralized and parallel information fusion, which are not scalable, are hard to adapt to changing topologies, and suffer from points of vulnerability and information bottlenecks.  The research considers large scale networks of agents and studies how global (rational or irrational) patterns of behavior emerge, including herds, contagions and bubbles in economics. An understanding of how the biotic environment influences collective behavior in animal societies provides a real world guide to good cognitive networks, which can be used in turn to design engineered systems. Cognitive networks have applications in areas ranging from precision agriculture, to environmental monitoring, disaster relief management, and smart spaces.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes (200-800 words)

We studied stochastic network models along two main problems: distributed optimization and distributed diffusion.

Distributed optimization considers interactive networks of agents that only interact locally but aim at optimizing a global criteria. With the increasing digitalization of our world, data is collected by many sources; for example, medical records are recorded and stored in many hospitals or health care institutions. Privacy concerns may preclude sharing these data across the institutions. Nevertheless, it is important to carry out optimization of resources across all these institutions.  Distributed optimization addresses these problems. Each organization has their own local criteria (say, cost) and data, but the goal is to find a solution to the problem (find a global distribution of resources) that optimizes the combination (say sum) of all local criteria, without global sharing of the local data. We developed several classes of distributed optimization algorithms that are fast and provide a very good solution to the problem. We characterized their performance by establishing for each class their rate of convergence (how fast and how close the iterative search for a solution converges and gets to the optimal solution). We showed by analytical methods as well as by simulation how good the algorithms we developed are when compared with current alternatives available in the literature and published by other research groups.

Distributed diffusion considers emergent behaviors in large scale networks of loosely coupled agents. Each agent acts and senses locally, but, as observed in many colonies of biological agents (e.g., ants or bee colonies), or in diffusion of beliefs their combined distributed interactions lead to complex, coordinated behaviors. Applications of interest include also diffusion of opinions or memes in social networks, the spread of epidemics through a population, or addiction in a social network. We pursued questions like what is the impact of the network of contacts among individuals in the population in the spread of the epidemics or of the expansion of the addiction, or which subgroups of the population are most prone to being addicted or infected or changing their opinion. We were successful in addressing these questions for arbitrary contact networks because we proposed a new mathematical model to describe the evolution of the spread of epidemics (dynamics of the network process) and then were able to study this model as the agents interact among themselves. We established the probability that each individual in the population is infected or healthy (or, in the network of addicts example, stays addicted or recovers from addiction) after many interactions among the individuals in the population (time asymptotics). We also considered the problem of epidemics spreading among a very large population (network size grows very large). In this case we were able to derive a set of (deterministic) nonlinear differential equations that govern quantities like which fraction of individuals become infected and which fraction remains healthy as well as which fraction of pairs of individuals become infected or healthy. We were able to study the qualitative behavior of these nonlinear equations, addressing the more refined question of what fraction of the population needs to be infected initially before the epidemics survives or dies out. These problems traditionally have been considered assuming that each individual can contact equally any other individual. This is unrealistic. Our models and analysis have allowed us to consider the much more realistic case where each individual contacts only a restrict circle of other individuals (for example, their family members and a small circle of friends).

Our research has brought sophisticate mathematics to address real complex problems characterized by a very large number of agents (hospitals or individuals in a population) that interact among themselves (locally) but do not have access to the whole global population. Our models and tools allowed us to consider much more realistic set-ups than existing work and led us to find more refined answers to pertinent questions or to algorithms that can find better solutions than existing methods.

and model the interactions among agents through a jump Markov process. We study the asymptotics of this Markov process in the limit of large time (but with finite size population), or in the limit of large populations (and finite time).

The research carried out was punlished in 13 Journal papers and in 22 peer reviewed Conference papers. Four PhD students (two women) carried out and completed their doctoral researcn in the context of this project. One minority undergraduate student pursued a research project supported by an REU fellowship. Several Master students carried out research in this project. Prof. Jose' Moura, the PI of the project, gave numerous invited seminars at Universities all over the World, at Government Research Labs, and at several companies. He also gave numerous plenary talks and keynotes at international conferences.
